awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase II:  Structural Imaging of High Temperature Furnace Walls
awd_abstract_narration:
This  Small  Business  Innovation  Research  (SBIR)  Phase  II  project  aims  to  develop  a prototype 3-D imaging sensor for high temperature furnaces used in the glass industry. These furnaces are also used in many other industries, including cement, coke, iron & steel, and pulp & paper industries. This 3-D imaging sensor creates an interior image of the furnace wall so that maintenance personnel can identify wall erosion, and any molten material leaking through the wall joints.  The objective in Phase II is to develop a prototype sensor system that can form 3-D images of the interface between the furnace wall and molten glass. To achieve this, a high performance sensor hardware and corresponding imaging software will be developed. The entire prototyped system will be tested on high temperature furnace walls using in-house kilns followed by tests at an operational glass furnace. 

The broader impact/commercial potential of this project is that it will enable maintenance programs based upon real furnace conditions.  This will allow longer life span of high temperature furnaces and the ability to make informed local maintenance without a major interruption in production. This translates to significant financial savings for the glass manufacturing industry and improved safety, as several catastrophic accidents have occurred due to molten glass leaking from the furnaces.  The sensor technology also offers a platform on which many other applications can be built, including microwave medical imaging, archaeology explorations, and defect detection inside refractories during manufacturing.

por.por_cntn:
This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase II program of the Structural Imaging of High Temperature Furnace Walls project proposed to develop advanced sensors to monitor refractory wall erosion on high temperature furnaces used in glass manufacturing.  This program targets glass furnaces that melt the raw materials for glass production. As the molten glass flows through the furnace it erodes away the interior walls of the furnace to the point where they will start leaking molten glass. These leaks can occur suddenly and cause significant damage to the furnace and support equipment as well as present a potential personnel safety risk.  The technology supported by this program enable the accurate monitoring of the furnace wall thickness while the furnace is operating. By carefully monitoring the furnace wall thickness and erosion rate the glass manufacturers can optimize furnace operation for extended life and better forecast and plan for the furnace end of life shutdown.  This can translate into many months if not years of extended life saving millions in costs.

Our technology builds upon advanced radar technology and offers manufacturers a 3-D mapping of the glass penetration on the walls. During this program, we demonstrated extended feasibility of our technology on operational furnaces and built upon improving our capabilities to larger coverage of glass furnaces.

This program eventually supported the development of SmartMelter program, which is currently used by global manufacturers worldwide.
